translated: Jātaka
Twenty-Nipāta
Mātaṅgavagga
Hatthipāla Jātaka
“For a long time we have not seen
the brahmin who is like a god,
the great ascetic who wears matted hair,
with tusks and a mane.
For a long time we have not seen
the sage who delights in the qualities of the Dhamma,
wearing ochre robes,
with a bark garment as his upper robe.
Please accept our seat, water, and food,

analyzed: paṭigaṇhātu naḥ bhava  agghe bhavantam pucchāma
translated: we ask you, sir, for a price.
Please set a price for us.”
“By chance you should seek wealth,
having established your children and wife,
and having experienced all scents and tastes,
the sage is praised for the forest.”
“The Vedas are not true, nor is the gain of wealth,
by the gain of children old age is not overcome;
the peaceful ones say that scents and tastes are a hindrance,
one’s own actions are the cause for the attainment of results.”

analyzed: addhā hi saccam vacanam tava ita
translated: “Surely this statement of yours is true,
one’s own actions are the cause for the attainment of results;

analyzed: jiṇṇā ca mātā pitaraḥ tavi ime
translated: but these parents of yours are old,
Would they see him healthy after a hundred years?”
“Whoever has a witness to death,
and to old age, best of men,

original: Yo cāpi jaññā na marissaṁ kadāci,🔽Passeyyuṁ taṁ vassasataṁ arogaṁ.
analyzed: yo ca api jaññā na marissam kadāci  passeyyum tam vassa satam aroga
translated: and whoever knows, ‘I will not die,’🔽would they see him healthy after a hundred years?”
“Just as a man in a boat on the water
can make it go wherever he wants,
so old age and disease
always lead the mortal to the realm of death.”

analyzed: paṅko ca kāmā palipo ca kāmā
translated: “Sensual pleasures are a mire, a trap,
captivating, hard to cross, the domain of Death;
Entangled in this mire and trap,
they cannot cross over to the far shore.
This one formerly did evil deeds,

original: Svāyaṁ gahīto na hi mokkhito me;
analyzed: su āyam gahītaḥ na hi mokkhitaḥ me
translated: so now he is caught and not freed by me;
I will protect him from the she-wolf,

analyzed: mā ayam puna luddam akāsi kamma
translated: for he will do evil deeds again.”
“Just as a man in the forest searches for a lost cow,
so I search for my lost wealth, O King.
My wealth has been lost by this thief,

original: Sohaṁ kathaṁ na gaveseyyaṁ rāja.🔽Hiyyoti hiyyati poso,
analyzed: sā uham katham na gaveseyyam rāja  hiyyoti hiyyati poso
translated: so how can I not search for it, O King?🔽A person is carried away,
he goes and is lost,
Knowing that the future does not exist,
What wise person would remove the desire that has arisen?”
“I see a young girl, a mere child,
With a face like a ketaka flower.
In the prime of her youth, she has not enjoyed sensual pleasures,
Yet Death carries her away.

analyzed: yuvā su jātaḥ su mukhaḥ su dassanaḥ
translated: A young man, well-born, with a beautiful face, handsome,
Dark, with hair adorned with jasmine flowers;
Having abandoned sensual pleasures, he has gone forth from the house.

original: Anujāna maṁ pabbajissāmi deva”.🔽“Sākhāhi rukkho labhate samaññaṁ,
analyzed: anujāna mama pabbajissāmi deva  sākhāhi rukkhaḥ labhate samañña
translated: Give me permission, O King, I will go forth.”🔽“A tree is called a tree because of its branches;
But when its branches are cut off, it is called a stump.
Now that I have lost my son, I am a brahmin,
It is time for Vāseṭṭhī to go on alms round.”

original: “Aghasmi koñcāva yathā himaccaye,🔽Katāni jālāni padāliya haṁsā;
analyzed: aghasmi koñcāva yathā himaccaye  katāni jālāni padāliya hasā
translated: “I am like a crane in the cold season,🔽The nets are broken, the geese have gone.

original: Gacchanti puttā ca patī ca mayhaṁ,
analyzed: gacchanti puttā ca patī ca mayha
translated: My sons and husband have gone,

analyzed: sā aham katham na anuvaje pajāna
translated: How can I, knowing, not follow them?”
“These birds, having eaten and vomited,
Depart.
Those who have eaten and vomited,
Have come into my hands.
The brahmin has vomited sensual pleasures,
You will be the one who will be blamed.
A person who speaks ill, O King,

original: na so hoti pasaṁsiyo”.🔽“Paṅke ca posaṁ palipe byasannaṁ,
analyzed: na saḥ hoti pasasiyaḥ  paṅke ca posam palipe
translated: is not to be praised.”🔽“As a strong man would pull out a weak man
who is sinking and drowning in the mud,
So you have pulled me out of the mud,
O Pancala, with your well-spoken verses.”
After the Great King, the Lord of the Land,🔽the doer of good deeds, had said this,
he renounced the kingdom and went forth,
like a bull that has broken its tethers.
“The King has gone forth,
the best of men has renounced the kingdom,

analyzed: tuvam pi naḥ hohi yathā iva rājā
translated: You should be like the King to us,
govern the kingdom as we advise.”
“The King has gone forth,
the best of men has renounced the kingdom,
I will wander alone in the world,
having given up delightful sensual pleasures.
The King has gone forth,
the best of men has renounced the kingdom,
I will wander alone in the world,

original: Hitvāna kāmāni yathodhikāni.🔽Accenti kālā tarayanti rattiyo,
analyzed: hitvāna kāmāni yathā udhikāni  accenti kālā tarayanti rattiyaḥ
translated: having given up sensual pleasures as much as I can.🔽Time passes, the nights pass quickly,
the qualities of youth gradually disappear;
I, too, will go forth alone in the world,
Having abandoned the delightful pleasures of sense.
The days pass quickly, the nights pass quickly,
The years and seasons pass quickly;
I, too, will go forth alone in the world,
Having abandoned the pleasures of sense as much as is possible.
The days pass quickly, the nights pass quickly,
The years and seasons pass quickly;
I, too, will go forth alone in the world,
Having cooled down and having overcome all attachments.”
The Hatthipāla Jātaka is the thirteenth.
